channel.title: The Generalist Cookbook
channel.description: Recent content on The Generalist Cookbook

item.title: Adobe Acrobat ConnectorIcons
item.description: I have seen this a lot on Citrix app servers, not so much RDS boxes for some reason, the user’s profiles will fill up because of: C:\Users\xyz\AppData\LocalLow\Adobe\Acrobat\DC\ConnectorIcons\xyz.bmp Still not sure what causes this but they are just cached icons of documents You can safely delete them for all users using the following powershell script: Get-ChildItem C:\Users | Foreach-Object { Remove-Item -Path "C:\Users\$_\AppData\LocalLow\Adobe\Acrobat\DC\ConnectorIcons\*.
item.content:
• I have seen this a lot on Citrix app servers, not so much RDS boxes for some reason, the user’s profiles will fill up because of:

C:\Users\xyz\AppData\LocalLow\Adobe\Acrobat\DC\ConnectorIcons\xyz.bmp

  • Still not sure what causes this but they are just cached icons of documents

  • You can safely delete them for all users using the following powershell script:

Get-ChildItem C:\Users | Foreach-Object { Remove-Item -Path "C:\Users\$_\AppData\LocalLow\Adobe\Acrobat\DC\ConnectorIcons\*.bmp" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue -Force -Recurse }
  • Can even make it a scheduled task - who cares

item.title: Rclone on Windows
item.description: You can deploy Rclone on any Windows version using the WinFsp signed driver to provide access to anything Rclone is enabled for, including the Rclone crypt functionality, as a “mapped drive.” This is also great on legacy Windows versions that don’t support Files On-Demand. Most of this process is scripted to facilitate bulk deployments. Use below script to download, install and move required programs and files into place. $e="${env:SYSTEMDRIVE}\TempSPMount" mkdir $e; cd $e # Download and extract rclone Invoke-WebRequest -UseBasicParsing https://downloads.
item.content:
You can deploy Rclone on any Windows version using the WinFsp signed driver to provide access to anything Rclone is enabled for, including the Rclone crypt functionality, as a “mapped drive.”

This is also great on legacy Windows versions that don’t support Files On-Demand.

Most of this process is scripted to facilitate bulk deployments.

  • Use below script to download, install and move required programs and files into place.
$e="${env:SYSTEMDRIVE}\TempSPMount"
mkdir $e; cd $e

# Download and extract rclone 
Invoke-WebRequest -UseBasicParsing https://downloads.rclone.org/rclone-current-windows-amd64.zip -OutFile rclone-v1.55.1-windows-amd64.zip
Expand-Archive rclone-v1.55.1-windows-amd64.zip .
mv .\rclone-v*\*.exe .
rm rclone-* -Recurse -Force


# Download and install WinFSP
Invoke-WebRequest -UseBasicParsing https://github.com/billziss-gh/winfsp/releases/download/v1.9/winfsp-1.9.21096.msi -OutFile winfsp-1.9.21096.msi
msiexec.exe /i winfsp-1.9.21096.msi

# Download and extract nircmd
Invoke-WebRequest -UseBasicParsing https://www.nirsoft.net/utils/nircmd-x64.zip -OutFile nircmd.zip
Expand-Archive nircmd.zip
mv nircmd/nircmd.exe .
rm nircmd -Recurse -Force
rm nircmd.zip -Force 

.\rclone.exe config
  • Follow the Rclone configuration wizard to mount your drive and make a note of what you called it initially
  • Create a scheduled task to mount your drive on login using the below syntax for the command
"yourpath\nircmd.exe" exec hide "yourpath\rclone.exe" mount TempSPMount:/ X: --vfs-cache-mode writes

Your desired storage will be mounted as the “X:” drive on the Windows user’s computer on sign in.
